media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - APRIL 06: Dr. Lisa Dabby, 41, left, an emergency room physician with UCLA Medical Center in Santa Monica talks with nursing staff at the entrance to the temporary initial screening area assembled in the covered entrance to the hospital emergency room where they are on the front line of the coronavirus COVID-19 outbreak. During a typical 10-hour shift, she treats appendicitis, overdoses, skateboard accidents, arrhythmia, the usual off-the-street accidents, illnesses and conditions that flare up without notice. With more than 10 years at the hospital, she knows what to expect and how to treat it, but the coronavirus has changed that. She treats about 20 patients a day who arrive with coughs, fevers, shortness of breath and the fear and uncertainty that this pandemic has brought. UCLA Medical Center, Santa Monica on Monday, April 6, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Glowing blue waves lighting up SoCal coastline roll into the South Bay
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Mark Potts, Jay L. Clendenin
item.description: Video and photos show an algae bloom in the South Bay producing a neon-blue light along the shoreline at night in Hermosa Beach.
item.content:encoded: Video and photos show an algae bloom in the South Bay producing a neon-blue light along the shoreline at night in Hermosa Beach.

media:content.media:description: HERMOSA BEACH, CA - APRIL 25: Bioluminescent waves glow off the coast of Hermosa Beach, CA, Saturday, April 25, 2020. The phenomenon is associated with a red tide, or an algae bloom, filled with dinoflagellates which react with bioluminescence when jostled by the moving water. During the daytime, due to the pigmentation of the dinoflagellates, the water can turn a deep red, brown, or orange color, giving red tides their name.(Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin/Jay L. Clendenin/Los Angeles Times

The test site is located at 100 Constitution Avenue on the VA campus. The tests are self-administered, and people are instructed on how to swab their own mouths/throats when they arrive. item.title: Two years ago, she competed on 'The Voice.' Now she's the star of a coronavirus block party
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: A former contestant on "The Voice" leads a weekly performance in her Upland cul-de-sac where neighbors connect to get through the pandemic together.
item.content:encoded: A former contestant on "The Voice" leads a weekly performance in her Upland cul-de-sac where neighbors connect to get through the pandemic together.

media:content.media:description: UPLAND, CA - APRIL 16: Alexa Capelli, a 20-year-old singer, who lives in the culdesac, sings at her neighborhood weekly gathering. Neighbors living in a culdesac of Upland got together and hold Neighborhood Safe Social Distancing gathering on weekly basis to keep the mood upbeat in the midst coronavirus pandemic. Alexa Capelli, a 20-year-old singer, who lives in the culdesac at 1400 block of Highpoint Street, entertains the neighbors with beautiful songs. Neighbors, who come from different professional background, like occupational therapist, law enforcement, school teacher, medical office administrator, x-ray technician and owner of thrift store, bring out their lawn chair and tables, sipping on their favorite drinks enjoy the weekly musical evening. Upland, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, April 14, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. On a near daily basis since outlining his criteria for someday easing stay-at-home orders, Newsom, who recently allowed scheduled surgeries to resume, has warned Californians that, while he understands their desires to get back to work and a sense of normalcy, lifting the orders too soon could be a public health mistake. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

media:content.media:description: MADERA, CALIFORNIA-APRIL 8, 2020-Juan Infante, a certified medical assistant, takes the temperature of a patient (who approved her photograph being taken) before she gets tested for Covid-19. Camarena Health Center is working together with the Madera County Rapid Contact Tracing Team to help identify and isolate people who have tested positive or come into contact with a coronavirus carrier. The Madera County Rapid Contact Tracing Team is a model program to identify anyone who has come into contact with a person who tests positive for Covid 19 coronavirus. They identify those who need to go into home quarantine and possibly house them at a hotel if needed. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Skelton: In the coronavirus crisis, California isn't under one-party rule, it's under one-man rule

item.description: Power abhors a vacuum. With the legislative and judicial branches basically shut down because of the coronavirus, the executive has seized almost complete control over state government.
item.content:encoded: Power abhors a vacuum. With the legislative and judicial branches basically shut down because of the coronavirus, the executive has seized almost complete control over state government.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, April 14, 2020, file photo, California Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses an outline for what it will take to lift coronavirus restrictions during a news conference at the Governor's Office of Emergency Services in Rancho Cordova, Calif. On a near daily basis since outlining his criteria for someday easing stay-at-home orders, Newsom, who recently allowed scheduled surgeries to resume, has warned Californians that, while he understands their desires to get back to work and a sense of normalcy, lifting the orders too soon could be a public health mistake. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool, File)

Col. Sachs appealed to the public for birthday cards after the coronavirus pandemic forced the cancellation of a big celebration and wound up receiving thousands, including a letter and photo from President Donald Trump. item.title: L.A. County reports 18 new coronavirus deaths, says poor people are three times more likely to die
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 18 additional COVID-19 deaths and 440 new cases of the coronavirus and said that people in lower-income communities are three times more likely to die of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 18 additional COVID-19 deaths and 440 new cases of the coronavirus and said that people in lower-income communities are three times more likely to die of COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.content:encoded: Orange County health officials announce 124 new cases and two more deaths, for a total of 1,969 confirmed cases and 38 deaths. The county will launch a testing network Tuesday.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 2020: Denise Martinez, of Costa Mesa, kneels down in prayer in front of the closed Huntington Beach pier as she spreads her message of love, not the anarchy that she says some of the stay-at-home protesters want. "I'm out here praying for the city," Martinez said. "And to show an example of Christ, who is love. Our freedom doesn't come from a spirit of anarchy. Right now our main focus is loving each other at any cost. The lord says today that he hears the cries of his people and to trust him. Because love overcomes everything." Beach-goers enjoyed warm summer-like weather amid state and city social distancing regulations to stave off Coronavirus mandated by Gov. Newsom in Huntington Beach, CA, on April 22, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Isolation and boredom of staying at home can be harmful in their own way, experts say

item.description: The psychological harm of the lockdown is harder to measure and likely to last longer, driving up the rate of domestic violence, depression and another mental conditions.
item.content:encoded: The psychological harm of the lockdown is harder to measure and likely to last longer, driving up the rate of domestic violence, depression and another mental conditions.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - APRIL 24, 2020 - - Dr. Steven Siegel, 55, a psychiatrist and Chair of the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Studies with the Keck School of Medicine at USC, stands with his dog Philly outside his office where he works at his home in Glendale on April 24, 2020. Dr. Siegel recommends that people maintain a routine to help them deal with mental stress during the stay at home order during the coronavirus pandemic. His routine involves waking at 5 each morning, feeding his dogs, having breakfast, dressing and working in his spare bedroom which he has converted into an office. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA -- FRIDAY, APRIL 24, 2020: An empty lounger at the Beachcomber Inn with a scenic view of an empty, closed beach and pier due to coronavirus pandemic social distancing restriction amid a heat wave at San Clemente beach in San Clemente, CA, on April 24, 2020. In San Clemente the local council voted to reopen the beach for recreational activity such as walking, running, swimming and surfing, but have also said residents should not bring a blanket and hang out starting Saturday morning at 6am. The city is attempting to limit access to local residents by keeping parking lots closed, and other Orange county officials have urged out-of-town residents not to visit the beaches and parks that remain open. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Coronavirus threatens a South L.A. clinic that's long been a lifeline for the working poor
item.dc:creator: Esmeralda Bermudez
item.description: Due to Coronavirus, many patients have stopped going to community clinics, putting funding at risk
item.content:encoded: Due to Coronavirus, many patients have stopped going to community clinics, putting funding at risk

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 08: During the coroniavirus pandemic a woman carries an infant out of entrance to South Central Family Health Center (SCFHC) as people wait to get speak with the medical assistant at the entrance on Wednesday, April 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. For decades, the South Central Family Health Center has been a refuge for low-income families most at risk. They rely on the clinic for medical help; also for help with homeless services, food coupons and emotional support for domestic violence. In recent weeks, so many patients have stopped attending the clinic due to Coronavirus fears, it's put the clinics funding at risk. Officials have furloughed employees, slashed services and put major projects on hold. They said worry that after the pandemic ends, the clinic may not be able to stay open or will only offer a fraction of the critical services it's known for. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Mosques raise a big part of their budget during Ramadan. Under coronavirus quarantine, key funding is at risk
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: During Ramadan, mosques around the country are able to raise as much as 30% of their annual revenue through charity from congregants. But as mosques shut their doors under coronavirus quarantine orders, they have been taken a financial hit.
item.content:encoded: During Ramadan, mosques around the country are able to raise as much as 30% of their annual revenue through charity from congregants. But as mosques shut their doors under coronavirus quarantine orders, they have been taken a financial hit.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 22: The Islamic Center of Southern California off of Vermont Avenue on Wednesday, April 22, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Mosques have been put at risk of laying off staff members, including imams, because of losing money during the COVID-19 pandemic. Ramadan is typically a huge fundraising time for mosques, which in some cases can raise as much as 30% of their yearly budget over the holiday. In Southern California, many mosques are feeling the loss and are worried about what losing more money could mean for their futures. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.description: Coronavirus: As the pandemic emerged, so did the story of Lupe Hernandez, a Bakersfield nurse who was reported to have invented hand sanitizer. Her story has become an urban legend.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: As the pandemic emerged, so did the story of Lupe Hernandez, a Bakersfield nurse who was reported to have invented hand sanitizer. Her story has become an urban legend.

media:content.media:description: A photograph of Josephine Lupe Hernandez (left) has been circulating online attached to the story of a Latina who supposedly invented hand sanitizer in Bakersfield. But the deceased woman lived in Colorado, and there's little chance she's connected to the story. GOJO Industries, creators of Purell hand sanitizer, say its founders created early versions of hand sanitizer.
